description.narrative: Strengthened capacities of government and producer institutions to design, develop and deliver key services and Mainstreaming & operationalization of Disaster Risk Management policy.
populated place

To support local communities and administrations at the lowest level of government to design and implement adaptation actions aimed at reducing vulnerability and building resilience, especially in those communities that are particularly vulnerable in Ethiopia
Capacity perception index, disaggregated by Gender

comment.narrative: Average CCA capacity scorecard rating of 1.26 across men and women
CCA capacity scorecard rating is increased to an average of 3 in target Woredas for both men and women

Since the inception of the project implementation, the project has been providing different capacity building trainings to enhance institutional capacity at lowest administrative levels, mainly at the 4 Woredas and the 8 Kebeles ( Mesebo &Mesret kebeles in Enderta woreda,) (Selga 23 & Kushmengel kebeles Asossa woreda), ( Desta Abijata &Kemo Gerbi kebeles in Adami Tulu Jido Kombolcha woreda) and (Pukong&Pimoli kebeles in Gambela Woreda ), on how to engage in multi-stakeholder dialogue; assess situation; create a mandate and vision; formulate policy and strategy; budget management and implementation as well as monitoring and evaluation. Based on this support, task team members have been able to design and provide mentoring support to beneficiary community members at the Kebele level in integrating and implementing new CC adaptation techniques and technologies. Furthermore, beneficiary farmers have gained practical knowledge on participatory planning methods. In so doing, capacity in properly designing and implementing CC adaptation measures that would reduce vulnerability and build the resilience of local communities to climate change in the PAA pilot Kebeles and in Addis Ababa has improved. In general, the institutional capacity is improved for a total of 333 (88 F&245 M) woreda task team members,DA agents & Woreda task teams, from the baseline 1.26 to 2.85 score.

description.narrative: Adaptation actions implemented in national/sub-national development frameworks

comment.narrative: Limited mainstreaming of adaptation into national food security and land management programmes
By the end of the project at least two national programmes have mainstreamed climate change adaptation in to their based on lessons learned from this LDCF project

In order to help a national level mainstreaming of climate change adaptation,the project has started documenting the best practices that would be lessons to be shared to sub-national and national levels which can positively influence decision makers to mainstream CC adaptation into national food security and land management programmes
Limited mainstreaming of adaptation into sub-national planning processes and policies
By the end of the project at least four Woreda and one Regional development plan have been revised to incorporate climate change risks and opportunities

Based on the four Woredas CC adaptation plans, all Woredas have revised their development plan. These plans are now part of the Woreda Development Plans in which CC issues are incorporated. Following the plan revision, all woredas have started transforming to implementation.

description.narrative: Increase in climate resilient agricultural production in the target areas

comment.narrative: Currently, only ad hoc adoption of adaptation measures by subsistence farmers, and agriculture is climate vulnerable.

By the end of the project, 5000 subsistence farmers have adopted adaptation measures and climate resilient agricultural production has increased by 12.5% in target areas compared to baseline (1t/ha maize) and for adjusted for rainfall.

In order to improve farmers' access to technologies and practices that have CC adaptation value the project provided material and technical as well as training support to a total of 4479 (2547 male which is 51% of the target and 1932 female which is 39% of the target) farmers and they have been implementing, different CC adaptation technologies such as climate resilient agricultural crop and vegetable production through small scale irrigation using rain water harvesting techniques, shallow well drilling and application of solar pumps and by applying drip irrigation techniques, river diversion techniques, on a total of 1,200 hectares of land across all sites. On so doing they have been able to harvest more production. in general, the average growth of productivity in all production items is estimated to grow by 300% from the baseline production level across all pilot sites. This shows that there has been an increased production by 287.5% when compared to the expected target set at the end of the project period

description.narrative: Institutional capacities for coordinated climate-resilient planning and investment strengthened.
Number and type of targeted institutions with increased adaptive capacity to minimise exposure to climate vulnerability Capacity perception index ,disaggregated by gender.

comment.narrative:
By end of Project, 4 Woreda and 1 Regional task teams have been trained in and use climate related vulnerability and risk assessments in an integrated area-based planning approach,
Average CCA capacity score in the 4 Woreda and 1 Regional level is 3 for both men and women.

As follow-up practice from year 2014, the project continued providing training and mentoring support to all the 4 pilot rural Woredas and the 8 Kebele pilot sites as well as in Addis Ababa city government. Accordingly, in this reporting period, training and mentoring support was provided to 264 (79 F & 185 M) Woreda level task team members including planning experts, local level government representatives and local community members. The trainings have focused on how to: - Engage in multi-stakeholder dialogue; - Assess a situation and create a vision and mandate; - Formulate implementation policy and strategy; - Budget, manage and implement the planned intervention; and - Monitor and evaluate progress and feed back into the implementation management. After the trainings, those who participated in the trainings have used the knowledge to undertake climate related vulnerability and risk assessments in an integrated area-based planning approach in their respective Woredas - the Woreda Task teams used the skills and knowledge they acquired from the training and undertook climate related vulnerability and risk assessments in an integrated area-based planning approach in their respective Woredas. Apart from training support, "Simple pictorial-based information sheets on climate change, its causes and effects" designed for local community consumption was prepared and have been distributed to local level decision makers, planners and extension agents, in order to facilitate easy access to climate change related information. Capacity building support was also provided to 54 (8 F & 46 Male) in the 4 rural Woreda and to 15 (1 F & 14 M) task team members in Addis Ababa project task team members, to prepare area-based climate vulnerability profiles and climate risk analyses using GIS tools as part of the learning by doing approach for the development of the integrated plans. After the training, task team members have been able to undertake vulnerability assessment and produce local level vulnerability maps and documents for their respective localities. All in all, it could be said that the institutional capacity score has increased from the baseline score of 1.26 to 2.85.

description.narrative: Adaptation actions implemented in national/sub-national development frameworks

comment.narrative: Institutional capacity for cross-sectoral climate change planning is negligible
Climate resilient investment strategies based on integrated climate resilient development plans are in place and attracting funding for 4 Woreda & 1 Regional area.

One of the main deliverable expected by the PAA project is the Addis Ababa green growth investment plan document which is going to be used for sharing lessons for other major cities in the Country. In this regard, in this reporting period, a consolidated Climate Resilient Green Growth investment plan for Addis Ababa is under preparation by a national consultant. The first draft was completed and it has been subjected to a peer-review by wider group of experts first. Currently, the consultant is incorporating the comments received from the review meeting. What remains is organizing a national stakeholders validation workshop to produce the final document.

description.narrative: Access to technologies and practices that improve the range and efficiency of adaptation options improved.
% of farmers adopting adaptation technologies, by technology type, disaggregated by gender.

comment.narrative: Farmers (83% male-headed, 17% female-headed) currently constrained by limited access to and knowledge of adaptation techniques and practices.

By the end of the project, 5000 subsistence farmers (83% male-headed, 17% female-headed) have been trained in and tested climate change resilience building techniques and practices, of which 35% of both male and female headed farming households have adopted them permanently.

In order to improve farmers' access to technologies and practices that have adaptation value, the project has provided material inputs as well as technical backstopping for beneficiary farmers and for communal actions undertaken for the purpose of environmental rehabilitation of forests or pasturelands, catchment management. Thus, in this reporting period in all project sites:
- Climate resilient conservation agriculture and crop diversification practices with the use of drought resistant crop varieties implemented; Small scale irrigation to grow market demanding fruits and vegetable crops through using rainwater harvesting technologies, low cost drip irrigation systems, human powered semi rotary water pumps and small to medium sized solar generated water pumps were implemented ; - improved bee keeping technologies and practices for honey and wax production that could improve the productivity and quality of the produce were supported by provision of modern beehives and accessories; - livestock production mainly goat and sheep production and fattening programme were implemented; - Development and use of household biogas energy and also production and use of energy efficient stoves were undertaken; - Environmental and natural resources management through area closure, construction of physical soil conservation measures, forest tree planting, and other similar practices were undertaken.
In order to enable farmers and woreda and kebele officials test the prioritized adaptation measures and technologies, practical trainings were provided and an experience sharing field demonstrations were organized by the project to a total of 832 (399 F & 433 M) farmers, 40 Developments Agents (DAs) and 44 woreda Task Team members The trainings focused mainly on different CC adaptation technologies including: Climate resilient agricultural crop and vegetable production practices; Modern and environmentally friendly animal husbandry mainly goat and sheep husbandry and fattening practices; modern apicultural practices including small scale irrigation using rain water harvesting techniques, shallow well drilling and application of solar pumps and by applying drip irrigation techniques; river diversion techniques; rehabilitation of degraded ecosystems; production and use of energy efficient stoves; and use of house holds level biogas energy production and use. Following the trainings, a total of 4479 (2547 male which is 50.94 of the target and 1932 female which is 38.64 of the target) farmers have been implementing above mentioned CC adaptation technologies and actions on their farm plots as an integrated set of adaptation actions on a total of 1,200 hectares of land across all sites.

description.narrative: Strengthened capacity of extension agents to transfer appropriate adaptation technologies by capacity score

comment.narrative: Currently there is only anecdotal evidence of capacity to transfer adaptation technologies score average 1.4
By the end of the project 5 project task teams from 4 Woreda and 1 Regional administration have the capacity to transfer adaptation technologies with capacity score of 3

In this reporting period, the additional trainings, experience sharing visits organized by the project, and the overall exposure to CC adaptation technologies have contributed highly to all extension agents and all the l woreda and Addis Ababa task teams in terms of enhancing their capacity to first understand, identify, select, and transfer adaptation technologies. Accordingly, the project task teams and extension agents from the 4 Woreda and Addis Ababa City Government have been involved actively in properly transferring adaptation technologies to beneficiary farmers. Hence I would say that the capacity of all task team members across all Woredas to transfer adaptation from has improved from the baseline score 1.26 to 2.85.

description.narrative: Capacity for community-based climate change adaptation improved.
% of targeted population covered by innovative insurance mechanisms, disaggregated by gender.

comment.narrative: Informal coping strategies are in use in target areas, no formal financial risk reducing/insurance approaches yet in place due to lack of meteorological and hazard information in target areas
By the end of the project at least 25% of the men and 25% of the women in the target communities are using innovative mechanisms to insure against the inherent uncertainty of climate change

In order to facilitate the access to climate information, which is considered as a constraining factor in reducing vulnerability to the perceived seasonal unpredictability of weather in all the PAA project sites including in Addis Ababa, different activities have been performed in this reporting period. Support was provided to the National Meteorological Agency (NMA) to present its available downscaled weather forecast information, which could be used for seasonal projections and/or longer term climate related projections for risk planning, to target Woreda level planners and beneficiary farmers in a way that they can find it useful and gather feedback in a way that improves their own forecasting. In order to create awareness and sufficient understanding to Woreda planners, DAs and Kebele level officials on downscaled weather data and on how to interpret this data to climate information and adjust their interventions and disaster risk management plans, different training sessions were organized by the project to a total of 1128 (487F & 641M) participants from across the project sites. Due to the these trainings, Woreda and local level awareness about the issue has increased substantially and about 38.96 female and 51.28 male target beneficiary communities have started using climate data effectively in their decision making processes. Thus, in general, the average growth of productivity in all production items is estimated to grow by 300% from the baseline production level across all pilot sites. This shows that there has been an increased production by 287.5% than when compared to the expected target set at the end of the project period. Due to this increase in productivity beneficiary farmers' income has increased and substantially supported their livelihood.

description.narrative: Increase in climate resilient agricultural productivity in the target areas

comment.narrative: Very limited capacity for applying climate resilient agriculture
By the end of the project, climate resilient agricultural production has increased by 12.5% in target areas compared to baseline (1t/ha maize) and for adjusted for rainfall.

In this reporting period, through the project support, 8 Automatic Weather Stations in all the 8 PAA project Kebele sites were installed. Accordingly, collection of real time weather information was made possible using these Automatic Weather Stations (AWSs). The data from the AWSs were directly transmitted to NMA server and the processed information from NMA is sent back to the 8 Kebeles through Woreda offices. Thus, currently Woreda level planners, DAs and farmers have been able to access realistic and up-to-date short term (seasonal) weather projection data. Using the information provided, beneficiary farmers have been able to make proper decision on their agricultural practices and have been able to get an increased production from their farm plots. Thus, the average growth of productivity in all production items is estimated to grow by 300% from the baseline production level across all pilot sites. This shows that there has been an increased production by 287.5% than when compared to the expected target set at the end of the project period. Furthermore, in order to insure community members against inherent climate change induced uncertainties the project has supported the design of weather index insurance mechanisms for each of the pilot kebeles and started covering the crop insurance premiums for 1840 interested beneficiary farmers in the pilot Kebeles to test and refine the design of the scheme farmers who are interested in the insurance mechanism.

description.narrative: Capacity of key sectors strengthened for accessing and make use of climate information and early warning. Enhance capacity of National Meteorological Agency (NMA) and Hydrology and Water Quality Department.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
To strengthen the climate monitoring capabilities, early warning systems and available information for responding to climate shocks and planning adaptation to climate change in Ethiopia.
1. Capacity as per capacity assessment scorecard. 2. Domestic finance committed to the relevant institutions to monitor extreme weather and climate change.

comment.narrative:
1. Limited capacity to generate EWS and CI on a national scale for extreme hydro-meteorological phenomena. There are no Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) for alert communication by NMA to DRMFSS.
Current score: 83. 2. Existing budget plans do not have sufficient funds to maintain and operate the environmental monitoring infrastructure.
Current budget: low.
1. Capacity assessment scorecard score of 139. 2. Domestic target financing is 100M Birr per year.

40 AWS have been procured. One upper air radio sonde equipment has also been procured and is ready for installation. A meteorological mobile calibration unit and equipment have been procured and they are already functional. Automatic hydrological gauge telemetry equipment has been identified and is ready to procure. Capacity building training sessions for instrument technicians, forecasters and support staffs as well as awareness-creation events for local communities have been held in various parts of the country, particularly for all NMA meteorological Branch Directorates staff and meteorological observers.

description.narrative: Enhanced capacity of NMA and HWQD to monitor extreme weather and climate change.
1. Percentage of national coverage of the weather/climate and hydrological monitoring infrastructure. 2. Frequency and timeliness of climate-related data availability.

comment.narrative: With the exception of spare parts required to rehabilitate 200 conventional stations, most of meteorological equipment was ready for installation. However, the installation of the equipment and instruments was delayed as a result of difficulties to undertake civil works during the rainy season.

description.narrative: Efficient and effective use of hydro-meteorological and environmental information for early warnings and long-term development plans.

1. Percentage of population with access to improved climate information and flood and drought warnings (disaggregated by gender). 2. Development frameworks (e.g. GTP) that integrate climate information in their formulation. 3. Sector-specific EW products and strategies that integrate climate risks.

comment.narrative: This part of the project will be executed after all the equipment is installed and capacity building sessions are held for experts and at the community level. The execution of activities is planned to start in 2016.
